channel.title: Hacker News - English
channel.description: Hacker News articles summarized and translated to English

item.title: Microsoft and Google overstate job creation at Chile data centers
item.description:
Data centers like this are touted as engines of growth. In June, President Gabriel Boric announced that Microsoft’s hyperscale data center cluster would generate over 81,000 jobs. Construction workers inside Google’s data center in Quilicura.

item.title: A Lost IBM PC/at Model? Analyzing a Newfound Old Bios
item.description:
Enigmatic IBM EPROMs They came with no further identi­fication, and no hints about their origins, or what machines they may have come from. PC/AT BIOS revision Rev. 3 Date (US format) 01/10/84 06/10/85 11/15/85 P/N (internal/mask ROM) U27, even: 6181028U47, odd: 6181029 U27, even: 6480090U47, odd: 6480091 U27, even: 62X0820U47, odd: 62X0821 P/N (EPROM label) U17/U27, even: 6181024/5U37/U47, odd: 6181026/7 U27, even: 6448896U47, odd: 6448897 U27, even: 61X9266U47, odd: 61X9265 ID bytes: Model, Submodel, Revision level FCh, N/A, N/A a FCh, 00h, 01h FCh, 01h, 00h Technical Reference (with source code listing) March 1984 September 1985 March 1986 PC/AT model and main­board type 068, 099 (Type 1) 239 (Type 2) 319, 339 (Type 3) CPU clock supported 6 MHz (not tested in POST) 6 MHz (tested in POST) 8 MHz (tested in POST) Keyboards supported 84-key AT 84-key AT b 84-key AT101/102-key Enhanced Floppy drive types supported 360 KB1.

item.title: I Stopped Being a Climate Catastrophist
item.description:
A future with low rates of technological change is not one that is consistent with high economic growth. Climate advocates have arguably become more catastrophic about climate change in recent years, not less. ShareWhen Is Weather Climate Change.

Read more

item.title: Internet Archive's legal fights are over, but its founder mourns what was lost
item.description:
” “We survived,” Internet Archive founder Brewster Kahle told Ars. At the time, law professor Lawrence Lessig predicted that the Internet Archive would face copyright battles, but he also believed that the Wayback Machine would change the way the public understood copyright fights. The Internet Archive also began archiving—and then lending—e-books.

Read more

item.title: Why aren't smart people happier?
item.description:
Intelligence sounds pretty great. Naturally, people with more of this mental horsepower must live happier lives. This large, nationally-representative study from the UK finds that people who score the lowest on an intelligence test are a little less happy than everyone else, but that’s pretty much it.

Read more

item.title: Norway reviews cybersecurity after remote-access feature found in Chinese buses
item.description:
A Yutong electric bus in Norway. Authorities are tightening cybersecurity controls after hidden SIM cards were discovered during internal tests. Norway has launched a cybersecurity review after public transport operator Ruter discovered that electric buses supplied by Chinese manufacturer Yutong contained hidden SIM cards enabling potential remote access.

Read more

item.title: Ruby and Its Neighbors: Smalltalk
item.description:
The major player was ParcPlace, which was a spinoff of Xerox that provided Smalltalk tools. I taught an undergrad OO class in Smalltalk in 1997 and 1998 to students that wanted to be learning C++, and I remember telling them that Smalltalk programmers were paid more. Your main interfaces to the smalltalk system are a.

item.title: Gnome Mutter Now "Completely Drops the Whole X11 Back End"
item.description:
GNOME Mutter Now "Completely Drops The Whole X11 Backend" Written by Michael Larabel in GNOME on 5 November 2025 at 08:15 AM EST. 25 Comments The merge to GNOME Mutter has finally happened that "completely drops" the X11 back-end to make GNOME strictly focused on Wayland-based environments. GNOME 50 will continue supporting XWayland clients (apps / games) but moving forward strictly for Wayland-based desktop sessions.

Read more

item.title: The grim truth behind the Pied Piper (2020)
item.description:
The grim truth behind the Pied Piper3 September 2020ShareSaveRaphael KadushinFeatures correspondentShareSaveKate Greenawayduncan1890/Getty ImagesEntranced by his flute, the transfixed children of Hamelin followed the Piper out of town (Credit: Kate Greenawayduncan1890/Getty Images)Writers like the Grimm Brothers and Robert Browning may have shaped the Pied Piper legend into art, but it turns out the story is likely based on an actual historical incident. The Hameln Museum offers a sound and light Pied Piper re-enactment; local actors put on an open-air Pied Piper play during summer; and the souvenir shops hawk their own rat-inspired memorabilia. You can go home, if you wish, loaded down with Pied Piper T-shirts, fridge magnets, mugs and flutes.

Read more

item.title: Carice TC2 – An fully analog electric car
iOS 26.2 to allow third-party app stores in Japan ahead of regulatory deadline
item.description:
In June 2024, the Japanese parliament approved and enacted legislation that requires Apple to allow third-party app stores and payment providers on the iPhone. More recently, in August 2025, the Japan Fair Trade Commission established the Mobile Software Competition Act Guidelines. Under the new guidelines, platform operators like Apple and Google are banned from blocking or restricting the availability of alternative app stores and payment systems on their mobile operating systems.

Read more

item.title: A P2P Vision for QUIC (2024)
item.description:
In a nutshell, a STUN client sends a “Binding Request” to a STUN server. Each host will try to send a STUN binding request from its selected address to the paired address, and respond to STUN requests that it might receive from the peer. This server can then relay traffic between the two peers.

Read more

item.description:
It's fully open, from hardware to software. Radiant is designed to make that accessible to everyone. Radiant is an ongoing research project in personal computing.

item.title: An eBPF Loophole: Using XDP for Egress Traffic
item.description:
XDP only processes packets on ingress. - that's considered egress traffic by the host kernel. Why Traffic Control Isn't Good Enough A popular method for handling egress packets is Traffic Control (TC), another eBPF-based mechanism that allows for packet processing at both ingress and egress.

Read more
